values:
As usual, and without surprise, the Penn State Administration has decided to take steps again over the summer months to alter student life at Penn State. Over my years at the university, I know that these changes are never small. Instead they focus on a large, wide, broad sweeping social engineering scale that seeks to micromanage students. Whenever these changes occur, naturally the administration claims that it is for the better. In reality, we all loose something, a piece of student independence, autonomy, and freedom.

If can recall, I spoke earlier this summer regarding controversy over approving student groups on campus. A university administrator that controlled the approval of religious based student groups on campus denied a new group the ability to form under the statement that too many Christian based groups already existed. The result was naturally, a lawsuit against the university. This initial event spurred from the administration failing to do what was the most proper course of action from step one; have the students manage all groups, including religious ones.

The Undergraduate Student Government Supreme Court typically approves most student groups. It gives students the power to regulate, approve, and manage our student groups. This especially is useful since student groups receiving funding from student based fees (included in the semester bill) through the University Park Allocation Committee (UPAC). Thus, it makes sense. Student decide what groups receive funds for particular events, students decide what groups exist. It has always been an efficient and effective process. 

Instead of not making the same mistake again, the university decided to repeat the mistake. The newest measure was just announced by the administration yesterday. http://live.psu.edu/story/7738 In a sweeping and unprecedented change, Court will no longer have the power to regulate and manage student groups. This power now will strictly rest with the Penn State Administration.

The end result is that students and student governance have been placed under assault by the administration. Instead of students managing student government powers through making their own changes via the student ran legislative bodies, the administration found it fitting to curtail any democratic process. Instead it favored rule by tyranny. 

 It is unfeasible to assume an administrator can effectively and efficiently control approvals of student groups on campus. Students directly care about students and their needs. An upper level, distant, administrator cannot replace that.

Penn State, put student government back in the hands of students. Stop cutting back on student governance and preventing the democratic process.

I had the fortunate experience this weekend to take the beloved trip to the emergency room. Few people enjoy hospitals and the dreaded ER is the worst, especially when you are the patient instead of the visitor.

Usually, when bad things happen, all of us tend to ask ourselves why. Why did this happen to me? What did I do wrong? Why did I deserve this? Some of these questions were bouncing around in my head during my trip the ER and while I was bleeding on a stretcher.

I believe with all things in life, there is a lesson to be learned. As I laid waiting for some answer for my questions directed towards God and the heavens, I found a bit of a realization. Though my injury was severe, I was lucky. Be it a twist of fate, luck, or divine intervention, my injury was not as bad as it could have been. This was another chance for me to learn and grow with myself completely intact physically. All things happen for a reason and somebody, somewhere was watching out for me a few days ago.

Campaign season has indeed heated up. We are seeing numerous media reports, ads on TV, and campaign stops throughout the country. Campaigning takes a lot of effort and can push a person to their personal limits if they believe in their cause. It is a time and money consumer, but the benefits can be excellent.

Regardless of your political affiliation, I believe most people would find the current Kerry and Edwards escapade to be morally and ethically wrong. While campaigning is obviously extremely important, both of these gentlemen already hold positions of the utmost importance. Being a United States Senator is no small task or responsibility to snuff at.

When these gentlemen were elected to office, they owed the citizens a true level of representation that comes with a position of public service. However, since the campaign season began, Mr. Kerry was absent 89 percent of the time this year and 64% last year; Mr. Edwards has missed 32 percent. 
 
The democrats have at times shot themselves in the foot. Recently, they missed a good chance to try to defeat President Bush's competitive-sourcing initiative. The initiative  would privatize some government jobs, a horrid state of affairs as far as most unions are concerned. An amendment to erase rules allowing the government to let companies compete for business failed by a 48-47 vote. If Edwards and Kerry were present, they could have easily passed the amendment in favor of their cause. (After all, we know how some democrats do not enjoy competition of the free market and prefer the unions) This vote may cost Kerry some union support. Expect a campaign play up to unions.

Kerry and Edwards may have served the public for years, since Kerry was in Vietnam after all (did you know that?). However, that is no excuse for a dereliction of this duty. They have abandoned their congressional duties in pursuit of the presidency. These missed votes are on policy matters that are centerpieces to their campaign, yet little to no calls of hypocrisy have been made. 

Democrats may argue that the missed votes have not interfered with their senatorial responsibilities. I beg to differ. It is not fair and it is not right to the citizens of their respective states. Missing time in the Senate is also missing being able to be informed, negotiate, discuss, and fulfill the political process. People in public service must give their time 100% of the time. That is the nature of the business and devotion to your constituents.

Saddam connected to al-Qaeda-linked groups: Iraqi PM 
 
LONDON (AFP) - Saddam Hussein had links with terrorists like Carlos the Jackal and Abu Nidal and groups connected to al-Qaeda, Iraqi Prime Minister Iyad Allawi said on Wednesday.
"The record of Saddam shows very well his connections to international terrorists, like Carlos and Abu Nidal," Allawi told BBC radio.

"We know for sure that he had established links with chieftains in Sudan, to work closely with al-Qaeda and al-Qaeda style organisations," he said.

Allawi also defended the US-led coalition's move to go to war against Saddam, describing it as "a moral decision taken on ethical grounds."

Carlos, a Venezuelan whose real name is Ilich Ramirez, has been serving a life sentence at a top-security French prison since 1997 for a triple murder carried out in Paris in 1975. He planned a wave of spectacular hijackings and kidnappings in Europe in the 1970s and 1980s.

Abu Nidal, a prominent militant Palestinian guerrilla leader, was found dead in Iraq in August 2002.
